In summary, why I'm bullish on @omgkirbyDAO:

1ï¸âƒ£ Major vibes from these lofi beats and art
2ï¸âƒ£ Music NFTs are just starting to heat up
3ï¸âƒ£ DAO execution looks impressive
4ï¸âƒ£ Love the mission & vision

Go listen and find some faves: https://t.co/f2IxUSzrrh

Ultimately the mission of the DAO is to be a leading web3 music project, setting standards for decentralized music ownership, and be part of disrupting the music industry by providing new pathways for creators, musicians, and artists to succeed.

Some example initiatives being voted on now:
* omgkirby creates a track with high-visibility artist feature
* Create a grant system to help empower up-and-coming musicians.
* Host an industry-focused roundtable discussion

https://t.co/jAoUpnhiPR

omgkirby is also formed as a DAO, with a community treasury. I was instantly impressed with the activity & structure of the DAO.

They have 2 month long sessions. Each session has multiple initiatives, each run by a committee. DAO votes on initiatives.

In a trendsetting move for music NFTs, owning a omgkirby NFT gives you complete ownership of the song in its entirety, which includes:

* Master Recording
* Publishing rights
* Access to lossless 24-Bit stem masters (the individual pieces that make up the song)
This genesis collection of 3k NFTs combines hand-drawn art with a unique lofi track that is a collab between human and algorithms. https://t.co/4dWxd4dsAs

The omgkirby group has serious music talent. Formed 2 years ago, their account has over 1 million monthly listeners on Spotify, with some of the chillest lofi beats I've heard. 

https://t.co/RpdHN0sh0E

Latest pickup: @omgkirbyDAO. Instantly became my favorite NFT music collection.

@Metahero007 @beijingdou @councilofkingz @Just_in_Gains True, and we can thank them for bringing some mainstream attention, even if they are bastardizing the core concept ğŸ˜†
Kudos to @beijingdou, @councilofkingz, and @Just_in_Gains for sparking these thoughts after a great Space on the metaverse earlier today: https://t.co/NVnzxhksbu.

We know what the alternative is, and we know it's better. It may or may not be Sandbox, or Decentraland, or NFTWorlds, or a combo of others that gain success. But ownership and interoperability, stored on the blockchain, will be what we all define as the metaverse in 5 years.

Does this mean Meta's "metaverse" will fail? No. I just think time will show it won't be a real metaverse. 

Games like Fortnite already challenge the notion of traditional games, and show the appetite for broader interactive experiences like it, but also isn't a metaverse.

With these new web3 metaverses, you get to OWN and EARN in exchange for your time and commitment. That is the key. 

Meta and other "traditional" gaming entrants will focus on UX, believing they can build great games and VR experiences, but we know they'll be selfish in profits.

Does this ultimately become a big-corporation, closed wall argument vs. open-source, decentralized argument? e.g. Windows vs Linux, etc. I think it's easy to dismiss it as such.

Here's the thing though: one metaverse model is clearly better than the other.

In metaverses like @TheSandboxGame, @decentraland, and others, the time you put into the experience actually gives you something out of it. You can truly own land and what you build on the land. You can earn real rewards (currency tokens or NFTs, not just achievements/badges).

IOW:

A true web3 metaverse is like owning property in real life, and owning the items you you use everyday in your life.

A web2 world is more like like a vacation to an all inclusive resort. It's fun, but it's temporary and all you do is spend money/time.

As @cdixon put it, imagine if IRL you went to a hotel, but had to come naked and only wear the clothes in the hotel closet. And when you left the hotel, you had to walk out naked. 

That is gaming & web2 today. Closed walls, where the owner of everything is the platform creator.

Ownership and interoperability are what blockchains and NFTs provide. 

That means:
* Owning and building your own land. 
* Owning or bringing in your NFTs to be your 3D avatar, accessories, event passes, or more across metaverses.

A metaverse is not a real metaverse if it does not exist on a blockchain. If Meta is building their metaverse on their private servers, that is not a metaverse. It's just a game and/or VR experience.

How to respect holders?
* Months long claim windows, or even better, free airdrops
* Provide updates in multiple formats (sporadic summary updates in discord, recorded AMAs/spaces, blog/website summaries, wikis/docs for complex projects)

I love NFT projects, but it's becoming standard expectation that owners must constantly check Discord/Twitter for updates.
e.g. short claim/mint windows, abuse of discord #announcements posts, etc

Fostering engagement != punishing for being away a few days

Respect your holders.
